description:
From nil (“not any”) +‎ potent (“having power”) with literal meaning “having zero power” - bearing Latin roots nil and potens.
Coined in 1870, along with idempotent, by American mathematician Benjamin Peirce to describe elements of associative algebras.

entries.meaning: (algebra, ring theory, of an element x of a semigroup or ring) Such that, for some positive integer n, xn = 0.
examples: The rest of this book is devoted to determining the conjugacy classes and centralizers of nilpotent elements in L(G) and unipotent elements in G, where G is an exceptional algebraic group of type E8,E7, E6, F4 or G2 over an algebraically closed field K of characteristic p. This chapter contains statements of the main results for nilpotent elements.
